content.text: You want to see your baby initiate and carry out the whole sequence of sitting on their own without outside help.
There are two ways to sit:

ol: From standing on six points (like when crawling), baby shifts the pelvis backward, leaning on one arm, and pushes up to sit.
From laying on one side, baby leans on one arm and pushes up to sit.

content.text: Learning to coordinate upper and lower body movements is foundational to standing and walking.
When your child’s hands are free from supporting them and their shoulder belt muscles are strong enough, it’s time to develop the fine motor skills that will help them when they start school.

If you see that your baby is having a hard time achieving this milestone by the age of 11 months, you should consult with your pediatrician or an infant development guide to learn how to help your baby. These important abilities are the foundation of their physical, sensory and emotional needs. Here are some signs your baby may need help:

ul: Losing balance and falling backward and/or sideways when seated.
Sitting most of the time with one hand on the floor for balance.
Sitting in a “W” shape most of the time.
Pointing or flexing feet most of the time.
